title: How to View Shared Folders on Windows

steps.title: Right-click the menu.
steps.content: Right-click the menu. It's usually at the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Scroll down the left column and click Network.
steps.content: Scroll down the left column and click Network . This displays a list of computers that are a part of the network.

steps.title: Double-click the computer where you want to see shared folders.
steps.content: Double-click the computer where you want to see shared folders. A list of shared folders on the selected computer will now appear. The shared files will have an icon that look like a computer drive if they're on someone else's computer. [1] X Expert Source Scott St Gelais IT Consultant Expert Interview. 27 July 2021. If the files are shared but you have them locally on your computer, the folder icon will look the same, but it may have an additional icon or tag that says "Shared." [2] X Expert Source Scott St Gelais IT Consultant Expert Interview. 27 July 2021.

steps.title: Press ⊞ Win+S.
steps.content: Press ⊞ Win + S . This opens the Windows search bar.

steps.title: Type computer management.
steps.content: Type computer management . A list of matching results will appear.

steps.title: Double-click Shared Folders.
steps.content: Double-click Shared Folders . It's in the left column. [3] X Research source This expands a list of subfolders.

steps.title: Click Shares.
steps.content: Click Shares . You'll only have to click it once. A list of shared folders will appear.

steps.title: Right-click the menu.
steps.content: Right-click the menu. It's usually at the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Click Command Prompt.
steps.content: Click Command Prompt . This opens a terminal window to the command prompt.

steps.title: Type net share.
steps.content: Type net share . Just click the terminal window to start typing.

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter . A list of shared folders will appear.
